Request for Information on Health Technology Ecosystem

This regulation seeks public input on the development and integration of health technology ecosystems, focusing on digital health products and their impact on healthcare delivery and patient outcomes.
CMS Docket: CMS-2025-0050
980
Total Comments
721
With Attachments
May 28, 2025 to June 25, 2025
Date Range

Themes Distribution

Click on any theme to see positions, then click positions to see relationships

852 Support for Digital Health Infrastructure ‚ñº
üìä Highest agreement (98%): Interoperability and Data Exchange: Support Interoperability Initiatives
üìä Lowest agreement (0%): Interoperability and Data Exchange: Oppose Broad Interoperability Mandates
54 Oppose Digital Health Infrastructure ‚ñº
üìä Highest agreement (74%): Autonomy in Healthcare Decisions: Support Individual Autonomy in Healthcare
üìä Lowest agreement (0%): Use of Biometric Data and Digital IDs: Support Use of Biometric Data and Digital IDs

CMS-2025-0050-0002 2025-05-28 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0001
Digital Health Infrastructure: Oppose Digital Health Infrastructure Autonomy in Healthcare Decisions: Support Individual Autonomy in Healthcare
 Please revisit how we have to sign up for Medicare A and B at age 65 or face a life long penalty. most of us are NOT retiring but have to jump thru hoops to sign up for a health insurance that we DO NOT WANT or NEED at 65. Save yourself some $$ and have us sign up when we are ready to retire. I now ... 1 1/980 Please, in your technology foundation, make it easy to use. use picture icons if needed. The commenter expresses opposition to the current Medicare enrollment process, advocating for a more user-friendly system that respects individual autonomy in healthcare decisions. They emphasize the need for simplicity and accessibility in technology to accommodate aging individuals.

 PR-1: We commend CMS‚Äôs efforts to encourage providers, including those in rural areas, to leverage approved digital health products. As the developer of Behaivior Recovery (www.behaivior.com), a predictive digital health platform using wearable devices and designed for behavioral health recovery, we... 1 1/980 We urge CMS to adopt policies fostering reimbursement, interoperability, provider education, and infrastructure support to unlock the full potential of predictive behavioral health digital tools. The commenter expresses strong support for digital health infrastructure and interoperability initiatives, emphasizing the need for policies that enhance reimbursement and integration of digital tools. Additionally, they advocate for patient autonomy in managing their health through the use of predictive tools.

 Currently every Home Health, Hospice, Hospital, Clinic, Specialty Clinic has their own Electronic Medical Record (EMR) Software program. For our small home care agency in Iowa the cost of the EMR is very expensive approximately 20% of my revenue is spent on software license and support. Imagine if... 1 1/980 Imagine if CMS Provided one EMR for all Provider Types. The commenter advocates for a centralized electronic medical record (EMR) system managed by CMS, emphasizing the benefits of improved patient outcomes, cost savings, and streamlined data exchange. This clearly supports the development of digital health infrastructure and interoperability initiatives.

I must get between 250-500 pages each year, EVEN though I signed up for DIGITAL access only with my advantage plan! I called the advantage plan and it took them 3 months to see why ... 1 1/980 Totally unacceptable. Government waste on paper and postage! The comment expresses strong support for the integration of Personal Emergency Response Services (PERS) into the digital health ecosystem, emphasizing their role in improving patient outcomes and autonomy. Additionally, it advocates for interoperability initiatives to enhance data sharing and care coordination.

The benefits are substantial. CMS and beneficiaries are better protected from fraud due to identity theft. Providers identities are protected from misuse and authorizing claims for patients they never saw. CMS-2025-0050-0297 2025-06-16 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031

 See attached file(s) üìé 2 1/490 TD-16: Point-to-Point vs. Shared Network Models Point-to-point models like HL7 are inherently unscalable. Shared networks are emerging naturally from modern architecture. These market-driven shared networks are not based on TEFCA, FHIR, o... Any attempt by CMS or ONC to regulate the architecture of shared networks now risks solidifying outdated paradigms. The commenter expresses opposition to government regulation of digital health infrastructure, arguing that it could hinder innovation and entrench outdated standards. They emphasize the importance of market-driven solutions and performance-based outcomes rather than regulatory mandates.

 See attached file for (CMS-2025-0050 Digital Health RFI üìé 1 1/980 June 13, 2025 Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services Re: Docket (CMS -2025 -0050) Digital Health RFI On behalf of the Massachusetts Association of Behavioral Health Systems (MABHS), a statewide organization of... We urge CMS to reinstate virtual PHP services for Medicare beneficiaries for the following reasons: Virtual PHP achieves similar clinically equivalent outcomes such as reduction in symptoms, improved functioning, and participant satisfaction as in-person care; The comment advocates for the reinstatement of virtual Partial Hospital Programs (PHP) for Medicare beneficiaries, highlighting the benefits of digital health solutions in improving patient outcomes and access to care. It emphasizes the importance of individual autonomy in choosing virtual services, particularly for those facing barriers to in-person attendance.

CMS-2025-0050-0314 2025-06-17 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031 Health Freedom Defense Fund
Use of Biometric Data and Digital IDs: Oppose Use of Biometric Data and Digital IDs Autonomy in Healthcare Decisions: Support Individual Autonomy in Healthcare
 My name is Leslie Manookian, I am the president of Health Freedom Defense Fund (HFDF). I am writing to express our concerns as they relate to the request for information from HHS surrounding the "Health Technology Ecosystem" and what impact this will have on the liberties and freedoms of all America... 1 1/980 HFDF stands staunchly opposed to any biometric data requirement for any American to access healthcare and should such requirements come to pass, there MUST be permanent valid op-outs without impacting the type or quality of healthcare provided. The commenter expresses strong opposition to mandatory biometric data and digital identity requirements for accessing healthcare, advocating for individual autonomy and the right to opt-out. This reflects a clear stance against government mandates in healthcare technology.

We strongly support expanding access to digital tools that empower patients and improve care while ensuring that such advances do not risk excluding patients and overburdening providers. The comment expresses strong support for expanding digital health tools and emphasizes the importance of inclusivity and practicality in healthcare technology, indicating a positive stance towards digital health infrastructure. Additionally, it advocates for interoperability through TEFCA and highlights the need for patient empowerment and autonomy in healthcare decisions.

No one should be forced to provide any biometric data to access healthcare in America,... 1 1/980 There should be absolutely no digital ID requirement for any human being to access healthcare in America, ever. The commenter expresses strong opposition to digital IDs and biometric data requirements for healthcare access, advocating for individual autonomy and informed consent. Additionally, the emphasis on the right to control personal data aligns with support for enhanced data privacy measures.

Additionally, it supports the concept of universal digital identity credentials, indicating a belief in their potential benefits for healthcare.

The Patient ID Now coalition encourages the Administration to consider the MATCH IT Act of 2025 to address patient identification and matching through improving definitions and standardization, including standardization within USCDI. The comment expresses strong support for improving digital health infrastructure and interoperability, particularly through the repeal of Section 510 and the introduction of the MATCH IT Act, which aims to enhance patient identification and matching. Additionally, it emphasizes the importance of patient autonomy in managing their health information.

CMS-2025-0050-0465 2025-06-17 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Digital Health Infrastructure: Oppose Digital Health Infrastructure Interoperability and Data Exchange: Oppose Broad Interoperability Mandates Patient Privacy and Data Security: Oppose Additional Data Privacy Regulations ‚ö†Ô∏è
 It is good that CMA, ASTP/ONC and HHS are seeking input about Health Technology from each of the involved parties. I am an individual working for a payer but commenting as an individual and not on behalf of my organization. PA-1: For TEFCA, the common agreement can change over time and requires th... 1 1/980 I am not very interested in receiving bulk data from providers as this is a risk to us since the more data we as a payer receive then the more we data we are responsible for storing and delivering via the APIs. The commenter expresses concerns about the risks associated with receiving bulk data and the implications of interoperability mandates, indicating a preference for caution regarding data handling and privacy. Additionally, they highlight issues with the flexibility of current API standards, suggesting opposition to broad interoperability initiatives that may complicate data exchange.

We believe that by fostering an interoperable ecosystem built on open standards and intelligent data processing, we can empower individuals, support providers, and accelerate the nation's transition to a system that delivers better health outcomes for everyone. The comment expresses strong support for digital health infrastructure and interoperability initiatives, emphasizing the importance of open standards and intelligent data processing. It also advocates for enhanced data privacy measures and individual autonomy in healthcare, highlighting the need for patient control over their health information.

Executive Summary Leidos thanks the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Assistant Secretary for Technology Polic... We understand CMS‚Äô long-term vision of interoperability and urge the agency to continue to prioritize the patient digital health experience by supporting health policies and technology solutions that foster the growth of interoperability. It also advocates for enhanced data privacy measures and individual autonomy in healthcare decisions, reflecting a comprehensive approach to modernizing the healthcare ecosystem.

CMS-2025-0050-0562 2025-06-20 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Interoperability and Data Exchange: Support Interoperability Initiatives
 As for "provider directories", the most common queries of the public are: * Is this health care organization/location part of my plan? * Is this individual provider part of my plan? * Is this medication covered by my insurance plan? In my opinion, using FHIR for provider directories is not the bes... 1 1/980 CMS/HHS/ASTP need to find a way to aggregate all of this information into one place so it is easy to answer the above common queries. The commenter advocates for improved interoperability by suggesting the aggregation of provider directory information into a centralized system, which aligns with the theme of supporting interoperability initiatives.

 PC-4. What features are missing from apps you use or that you are aware of today? a. **What apps should exist but do not yet? Digital Health Infrastructure: Support for Digital Health Infrastructure Interoperability and Data Exchange: Support Interoperability Initiatives Patient Privacy and Data Security: Support Enhanced Data Privacy Measures Autonomy in Healthcare Decisions: Support Individual Autonomy in Healthcare

The comment expresses strong support for improving data exchange and leveraging technology, indicating a positive stance towards digital health infrastructure. Additionally, it advocates for interoperability initiatives and centralized management to enhance healthcare delivery, reflecting a commitment to improving patient outcomes and experiences.

Additionally, it advocates for enhanced data privacy measures and individual autonomy in healthcare decisions, reflecting a comprehensive approach to improving the healthcare ecosystem.

CMS-2025-0050-0792 2025-06-25 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031
Digital Health Infrastructure: Support for Digital Health Infrastructure Interoperability and Data Exchange: Support Interoperability Initiatives Patient Privacy and Data Security: Support Enhanced Data Privacy Measures Autonomy in Healthcare Decisions: Support Individual Autonomy in Healthcare
 Please see attached comment pertaining to radiology imaging integrity. üìé 1 1/980 Comment: CMS ‚Äì0042‚ÄìNC ‚Äì Request for Information on the Health Technology Ecosystem CMS must treat imaging transparency as an urgent regulatory priority. It should no longer be acceptable for hospitals to control or manipulate diagnostic data to protect institutional interests at the expense of p... Digital imaging transparency must become a core expectation of a modern health technology ecosystem. Hospitals should not be allowed to block, alter, or conceal medically necessary data. The commenter advocates for improved digital health infrastructure and transparency in imaging data, emphasizing the need for interoperability and patient access to their own health information. They express strong support for enhanced data privacy measures and individual autonomy in healthcare decisions, highlighting the detrimental effects of information blocking on patient safety and care quality.
CMS-2025-0050-0793 2025-06-25 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031 Memoir, Inc. d/b/a Chapter
Digital Health Infrastructure: Support for Digital Health Infrastructure Interoperability and Data Exchange: Support Interoperability Initiatives Patient Privacy and Data Security: Support Enhanced Data Privacy Measures Autonomy in Healthcare Decisions: Support Individual Autonomy in Healthcare

CMS can take several steps to improve developer interest and uptake to build products useful for Medicare beneficiaries: (1) CMS should invest in developing clear, usable APIs for companies to build upon. As the Clinical Director at the Direct Supply Innovation & Tech... 1 1/980 Ultimately, aligning regulations, incentives, and reimbursement mechanisms is essential for ensuring Medicare beneficiaries in nursing homes have equitable access to critical digital health technologies. The commenter expresses strong support for digital health solutions and interoperability initiatives, emphasizing the need for technological advancements to improve patient care and streamline processes in nursing homes. Their recommendations focus on enhancing access to technology and addressing systemic barriers, which aligns with the support for digital health infrastructure and interoperability.

Hospitals have strong commercial incentives not to make it easy for patients to take ... CMS-2025-0050-0884 2025-06-25 Comment on CMS-2025-0050-0031 RubyWell, Inc.

 PR-1. What can CMS and its partners do to encourage providers, including those in rural areas, to leverage approved (see description in PC-5) digital health products for their patients? It is critical to meet users where they are, especially those in rural areas, or with poor online access. RubyWel... 1 1/980 Solutions should address their pain points - reaching far-flung patients, communicating with care teams in real time while they are scattered over a large geographic area, low-connectivity solutions - and they should be rewarded for tech adoption that improves outcomes and creates efficiencies. The comment advocates for the use of digital health solutions tailored to the needs of providers in rural areas, emphasizing the importance of interoperability and communication. It also supports the idea of aligning incentives to encourage technology adoption that enhances patient care and outcomes.
